awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Low-cost, Wireless, Energy Harvesting Environmental Sensors
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project focuses on the development of a low-cost, wireless, and energy harvesting environmental sensor, and a data aggregation / visualization platform to enable effective communication of data to users and control systems. This project addresses major barriers in our main market, the application of IoT to the buildings sector, where complexity is encountered in the placement and powering of sensors in monitoring locations where access is limited. By reducing the upfront and maintenance costs of wireless sensor networks, the project allows cost-effective building sensor data collection of unprecedented longevity and density. These rich data sets in turn enable myriad benefits, including more effective building management controls and in-depth automated energy evaluations. The commercial availability of a low-cost, wireless, energy-harvesting environmental sensor would enable high-granularity sensing, feedback, and control to several additional markets including industrial, agricultural, and any other market application that would benefit from monitoring where power or access is in short supply. 

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project focuses on developing a low-cost, wireless, energy-harvesting environmental monitor using commercially available components and standard processes. An energy harvesting sensor of this type is not available commercially, and is uniquely enabling for building energy auditing and controls, supporting a new generation of automation and systems integration while eliminating the cost of extensive powered sensor installation or battery maintenance. This device was developed through Technology Readiness Level (TRL) 7 in Phase 1 of the SBIR program, in parallel with supporting data infrastructure, including dynamic cloud databases, data access via API methods and a beta data visualization platform. Phase II of the program aims to expand the scope of the low-cost, wireless, energy-harvesting environmental sensor from a network of low-power, short-range devices to a plug-and-play building-wide sensing solution, which includes the incorporation of additional hardware elements, including routers to extend the range of the low-power devices, and the development of automated data analysis strategies to extract valuable building information for the end-user.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.inst_street_address: 63 FLUSHING AVE UNIT 286, BROOKLYN NAVY YARD BLDG 292 STE 409

por.por_cntn:
This project has laid the groundwork for Radiator Labs' continued development of technology that uniquely combines sensor networks and data analytics in the application of efficiently controlling the distribution of building-wide steam heat. Applying new technology that increases the reliability and efficiency of buildings' existing steam heating systems saves energy, reduces retrofitting costs, and increases resident comfort.

Radiator Labs was started with its core product: the Cozy, an insulating cover that fits over a steam radiator and includes a fan, sensors, and computer. The computer constantly monitors the temperature of the surrounding air, and uses the fan to blow air through the cover and over the hot radiator when it gets too cold. It was quickly realized that combining data from Cozys installed over a majority of radiators in a building with other sensor data could be used to improve the overall efficiency of a building's heat distribution. Over the course of this project, Radiator Labs developed a new type of sensor for gathering additional building temperature data as well as algorithms, data pipelines, and visualization tools for converting the gathered data into improved building efficiency.

This project facilitated the development of Mera: a low-cost, low-power sensor that uses ambient light to power its gathering of ambient temperature measurements and their transmission to a centralized gateway for processing. The use of ambient light for power allows for significantly fewer maintenance visits to the installed networks of sensors, many of which are installed in apartments that are difficult to arrange access to. Over the course of this project, Radiator Labs installed a network of Meras in a building and was able to analyze the resulting temperature data in real-time.

This project also facilitated a dramatic improvement to Radiator Labs' data infrastructure. Radiator Labs went from a slow, batch-based data pipeline that sent temperature data to a centralized database every 10 minutes, to a consolidated, real-time system based on Erlang that retrieves sensor data in real-time. This has given us greater capability to diagnose heating distribution problems as they occur.

Radiator Labs also developed an improved dashboard that allows us to visualize trends in temperature for a given building over time. The dashboard allows users to graph temperatures from sensors over arbitrary timescales, as well as average temperatures for whole buildings and individual floors, apartments, and rooms.

Completing this grant allowed Radiator Labs to focus more generally on the problems of energy savings, increasing resident comfort, and heat distribution. This has enabled us to enter into more general product categories beyond the Cozy, like building automation and regulating energy consumption to smooth-out peaks and troughs in demand.


Last Modified: 12/30/2021
Modified by: Franklin G Palmer
